Subjective: Hard stools, difficult to pass, for 3 months. Bowel movements every 2-3 days. Abdominal pain, mainly cramps, painful when pressed. Bloated feeling, stomach more swollen. Underweight, long-standing, no recent loss. Impact: Difficult bowel movements, discomfort. No recent change in eating habits; already eats little, low appetite. No further weight loss. No blood in stool. No changes in urination. Regular periods. Family history: Sister with ulcerative colitis, patient denies similar symptoms. Request: Concern if serious, wants to soften stools permanently. Wants dietitian referral for underweight.
Objective: Abdomen: Normal bowel sounds. Varying tympani on percussion. No pain on palpation of renal lodges, upper abdomen, or lower right abdomen. Sensitive on palpation of lower left abdomen. Dampening on percussion of lower left abdomen. Abdomen appears a bit rounder.
Assessment: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation predominance. No alarm bells for serious conditions. Ruled out: Ulcerative colitis (different symptoms).
Plan: Explanation: IBS with constipation, not serious. Stool becomes hard.
Meds: Psyllium fiber sachets, daily, with plenty of water, for 6 weeks.
Safety Net: Return sooner if abdominal pain worsens, fever, or sudden lot of blood in stool.
Future Plan: Discuss dietitian referral for underweight at next visit.
